glossary.title: ISO 19650 BIM Terminology Glossary
glossary.description: Comprehensive glossary of BIM and ISO 19650 terminology for ML training

AIR.definition: Information requirements in relation to the operation of an asset
AIR.context: The AIR defines what information is needed to operate and maintain the built asset throughout its lifecycle
usage_examples: The AIR specifies the level of detail required for asset data
Asset Information Requirements must align with the organization's strategic objectives

BEP.definition: Plan that explains how the information management aspects of the appointment will be carried out by the delivery team
BEP.context: The BEP is a process management document developed by the delivery team in response to the EIR
usage_examples: The BEP outlines the strategic approach to information management
This BEP establishes clear protocols for model development and data exchange

CDE.definition: Agreed source of information for any given project or asset, for collecting, managing and disseminating each information container through a managed process
CDE.context: The CDE provides a single source of truth for project information with defined workflows
usage_examples: All project information shall be managed through an ISO 19650 compliant Common Data Environment
The CDE workflow comprises Work in Progress, Shared, Published, and Archive states

EIR.definition: Information requirements in relation to the appointment of a lead appointed party and appointed parties
EIR.context: The EIR defines what information the employer needs and when they need it
usage_examples: This plan responds directly to the EIR and the Employer's strategic objectives
All deliverables must meet the requirements specified in the EIR

Information_Manager.definition: Individual responsible for managing the information management processes in accordance with ISO 19650
Information_Manager.context: The Information Manager coordinates all information management activities and ensures BEP compliance
usage_examples: The Information Manager serves as the primary coordinator for all information management activities
The Information Manager chairs coordination meetings and manages the CDE workflow

Lead_Appointed_Party.definition: Provider of services relating to any information relating to the lead appointed party's appointment
Lead_Appointed_Party.context: The Lead Appointed Party coordinates the delivery team's information production
usage_examples: Lead Appointed Party responsibilities include overall project BIM coordination
The Lead Appointed Party must ensure all deliverables meet the Employer's requirements

Appointed_Party.definition: Provider of information concerning works, goods or services
Appointed_Party.context: Appointed parties are members of the delivery team responsible for specific work packages
usage_examples: Each appointed party must submit information according to the agreed schedule
All appointed parties must comply with the BEP and agreed standards

Task_Team.definition: Individuals organized to perform a specific task
Task_Team.context: Task teams are responsible for discipline-specific deliverables within the project
usage_examples: Task Team responsibilities include developing discipline-specific models to agreed standards
Each Task Team must designate a Task Information Manager

Level_of_Information_Need.definition: Framework which defines the extent and granularity of information
Level_of_Information_Need.context: Specifies how much detail is required at each project stage for decision-making
usage_examples: All models must be developed to the Level of Information Need specified for each project stage
The Level of Information Need ensures appropriate geometric and alphanumeric detail

Information_Container.definition: Named persistent set of information retrievable from within a file, system or application storage hierarchy
Information_Container.context: Files, documents, models, or databases that contain project information
usage_examples: The CDE includes clearly defined information containers for each discipline
Each information container must follow the project naming convention

MIDP.definition: Primary plan for when project information is to be prepared, by whom and using what protocols and procedures
MIDP.context: Coordinates all information delivery across the project lifecycle
usage_examples: The Master Information Delivery Plan establishes the overarching schedule for information delivery
The MIDP identifies key decision points requiring specific information deliverables

TIDP.definition: Plan setting out when the information is to be prepared by a task team, using what protocols and procedures
usage_examples: Task Information Delivery Plans detail discipline-specific deliverables
Each TIDP specifies the information container, format, and delivery date

Federation.definition: Creation of a composite information model from separate information models
Federation.context: Combining discipline models into a coordinated whole for clash detection and review
usage_examples: The Delivery Team shall produce coordinated federated models at key milestones
Federated model creation and maintenance is a Lead Appointed Party responsibility

Information_Model.definition: Set of structured and unstructured information containers
Information_Model.context: Digital representation of physical and functional characteristics of a facility
usage_examples: Information models must comply with the project's data schema
Each information model must pass validation checks before submission

PIM.definition: Information model relating to the delivery phase
PIM.context: Used during design and construction phases
usage_examples: The PIM includes architectural, structural, and MEP models
All PIM deliverables must meet Level of Information Need requirements

AIM.definition: Information model relating to the operational phase
AIM.context: Information handed over for facilities management and operations
usage_examples: The AIM supports space management and preventive maintenance
Asset Information Model data must be COBie-compliant for handover

Plain_Language_Questions.definition: Questions about the asset to be answered by the project team to inform decision making
Plain_Language_Questions.context: Drive information requirements and define what information is needed
usage_examples: Plain language questions inform the development of the EIR
Each information requirement should answer specific plain language questions

Information_Protocol.definition: Rules for structuring and naming information containers and their content
Information_Protocol.context: Ensures consistency in information production and exchange
usage_examples: All parties must follow the project information protocol
Information protocols include naming conventions and metadata requirements

LOD.definition: The degree to which the element's geometry and attached information has been thought through
LOD.context: Defines the reliability and detail of model elements at different project stages
usage_examples: Geometric modeling shall follow established LOD criteria appropriate to each project stage
LOD specifications ensure models contain sufficient detail for their intended purpose

COBie.definition: Standard for organizing and exchanging asset information
COBie.context: Structured format for handover information to facilities management
usage_examples: COBie-compliant data must be embedded within models
All COBie data must pass validation against the COBie UK 2012 schema

Clash_Detection.definition: Process of identifying conflicts between model elements from different disciplines
Clash_Detection.context: Critical coordination activity to identify and resolve spatial conflicts
usage_examples: Clash detection reports must be distributed within 24 hours of coordination meetings
3D coordination identifies and resolves spatial conflicts prior to construction

IFC.definition: Open standard file format for BIM data exchange
IFC.context: Ensures interoperability between different BIM software platforms
usage_examples: All models must be capable of exporting IFC 2x3 or IFC4 files
IFC exports are required for coordination purposes

Uniclass.full_name: Unified Classification for the Construction Industry
Uniclass.context: Standard classification for organizing construction information
usage_examples: Metadata requirements include classification according to Uniclass 2015 taxonomy
Classification verification ensures correct Uniclass coding
